speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the rash - is it itchy constantly, or only at certain times of the day?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's a bit itchy, especially when I scratch it. It feels like pins and needles sometimes, but it's not super uncomfortable. It's mostly on my arms and legs, but I did have a rash on my face too."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the duration of this rash - when did it first appear, and has it been getting worse or staying the same over the past few days?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started a week ago, and at first, it was just a tiny spot on my arm. It's been spreading a bit, but not too much. I'd say it's about the same size as it was when I first got it, just a bit more widespread now."

speaker: Doctor
text: So it's been a week since you first noticed it, and it's been spreading but not significantly in size. Can you tell me if you've experienced any other symptoms besides the rash and itching, such as swelling, redness, or pain?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah... I had a low-grade fever when it first started, and my nose was stuffy too. I also had a headache, but it went away after a day or so. My mom said I had a runny nose, but I don't really feel like that anymore."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the low-grade fever - was it more noticeable at night, and did it seem to follow a pattern, such as being higher in the morning or evening? And you mentioned a runny nose, but you don't feel that way anymore - do you experience any nasal congestion or discharge now?

speaker: Patient
text: "It was kinda the same, I guess. It was always there, but it wasn't super high, and I didn't really feel it too much. I'd wake up and feel okay, then feel a little warm later in the day. And yeah, my nose is still a bit stuffy, but not as bad as it was at first."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine the rash more closely. Can you please lift your arms and show me the affected areas, and also, can you point to the rash on your face for me? And, I'd like to request a test: REQUEST TEST: Complete Blood Count (CBC).

speaker: Measurement

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to take a closer look at the facial rash. Can you please turn your head slightly so I can see the affected area more clearly? Also, I'd like to ask, have you noticed any triggers that make the rash worse, such as heat, cold, or certain fabrics?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, okay... I think I can turn my head a bit. *turns head slightly* It's just a bit of a red patch on my cheeks and forehead, but like I said, it doesn't include my nose or lips. As for triggers, I don't really think so... I mean, I wear the same clothes every day and don't change my sheets often, so I'm not sure if that's a factor."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the type of itchiness you experience - is it more of a burning sensation, or does it feel like the skin is crawling?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more like... I don't know, it's hard to describe. It's like my skin is tingling, but it's not really itchy like I'd scratch. It's more like... a weird feeling, like my skin is being tickled, but not in a good way."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the sensation in more detail - is it more intense on certain areas of the skin, and does it seem to move around as you move your limbs? And, I'd like to request an additional test: REQUEST TEST: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR).

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like the patient's IgE levels are elevated, which could be indicative of an allergic reaction. speaker: Doctor
